| Motive (drive) | A need that is sufficiently pressing to direct the person to seek satisfaction of the need. |
|----------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------| Earlier this year, a comedy sketch on *Jimmy Kimmel Live* featured a mock TV game show that presented each of two contestants with a pair of luxury products and asked, “Which of these products is sh*t, and which is Shinola?” It wasn’t much of a challenge.
summary_markdown: The provided text defines "Motive (drive)" as a pressing need that compels an individual to seek its satisfaction. This definition is followed by an anecdote about a *Jimmy Kimmel Live* comedy sketch. The sketch involved a mock game show where contestants identified which of two luxury products was inferior ("sh*t") and which was superior ("Shinola"). The implication is that the distinction between the products was obvious, suggesting a clear difference in perceived value or quality, which could be linked to underlying consumer motives or desires. The anecdote serves as a lighthearted illustration, though its direct connection to the formal definition of "motive" is tangential, focusing more on product perception than the psychological drive itself.
